description.text:

Print out vase.stl and base.stl.  Put one within the other, and if you wish, wire up a LED light inside the vase.

_ Electrónica:

Utilicé la placa electrónica del siguiente enlace http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1430995 con ayuda del PLOTTER INK http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1367005. El soporte de electrónica está realizado a medida para esa placa.

2 x Servomotores HITEC HS-31
5 x Tornillos de 3mm x 10mm

1 x Tornillos de 3mm x 20mm

Software:

Realizado en ASSEMBLER, utilizando comunicación BT (HC-05) para lo que es el PIC 16F628A. Agrego el archivo .hex para cargarlo directamente al PIC16F628A.
La aplicación de control se creo para ANDROID mediante APPINVENTOR ( http://ai2.appinventor.mit.edu/ ).

Mutación:

Agrego el archivo en "Solidworks: .SLDPRT" para que lo editen y creen nuevas herramientas intercambiables.

_ Electronics:

I used the electronic board the following link http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1430995 with the help of INK PLOTTER http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1367005. Electronic support is constructed tailored to this board.

Hardware:

2 x Servomotors HITEC HS-31
5 x screws 3mm x 10mm
8 x screws 3mm x 15mm
1 x screws 3mm x 20mm
14 x Nuts 3mm

Software:

Made in ASSEMBLER, using BT communication (HC-05) for making it the PIC 16F628A. I add the .hex file to upload directly to PIC16F628A.
The control application was created for ANDROID by AppInventor (http://ai2.appinventor.mit.edu/).

Mutation:

I add the file to "Solidworks: .SLDPRT" for the edit and create new interchangeable tools.

title: Motorized Cap for Tulio's Marble Machine #3
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This thing is intended to replace the cap pieces of Tulio's "The 3D Printed Marble Machine #3" in order to allow me to attach a VEX robotics motor to run it.

It just seemed like it needed done.

https://youtu.be/HKn0BOGbLsw

Smaller Spiral

The included smaller spiral section was necessary because the spheres I'm using are slightly too large. This piece allows the blue marbles which I used to travel up the center of the machine. It seems to work okay, though not perfectly, for spheres of around 10-10.2mm in diameter.

I would have scaled the entire machine up if I'd acquired the marbles before printing, but I'd already printed the track by the time I realized my marbles were inconsistently sized and too large and I didn't want to print a whole new one.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

High

Infill:

Default

Need motor, half-inch square shaft, and 2 motor mounting screws. Use the square shaft to attach the Turncap to the motor. Use the screws to mount the motor (the screw heads should sink into the Lockcap). That's it. Just pop it onto the marble machine, and power it to go.

I imported Tulio's STL files into Sketchup using the SketchUp STL plugin.

For the Lockcap, I added VEX motor mount holes.

For the Turncap, I re-designed the base to connect with the motor using a square shaft.

For the Smaller Spiral, I separated the outside faces of the Spiral STL from the holes which fit into the Track and Turncap, and scaled those outside faces to 90.5% of their original size on the X and Y axes.

Powering the motor directly with a 9v battery To power the motor directly...

Cables should match:

  • Motor red to 9v black.
  • 9v red to motor black.

Powering the motor with a potentiometer in line. To be able to adjust the motor's speed...

Cables should match:

  • Motor red to 9v black.
  • 9v red to VEX potentiometer white.
  • VEX potentiometer black to motor black.
    (I used a VEX 3-wire "Y" cable as a coupler to connect these two male ends.)

comments.author: icefox1983

comments.text: Im having the same problem with Cura and S3D
comments.author: icefox1983

comments.text: Thanks for confirming that. This is clearly a slicing issue. I thought it's a cura bug/incompatibility but since you had the same problem with S3D it's hard to just blame cura. You should try my simple base I designed it to be easy to print and more accurate than this one.
comments.author: Robert1228

comments.text: Icefox, that happens because the Temperature you set is too high, so while the printer is printing, as it doesnt extrude the whole time (because it moves from different sides), the filament doesnt have time to go out on the rythme you set it, so in the heating area the filament melts and gets stuck within minutes, blocking the passage totally and making the print a disaster.
comments.author: icefox1983

comments.text: Thanks but I'm printing at 200c always, and have successfully printed many much more challenging designs (see my Makes). What I experienced was clearly a slicing issue. I watched it happen; the nozzle simply moved out of place and started extruding in the air, skipping many layers in the middle.
comments.author: TKP

comments.text: Another issue that you might experience is the high detail requirement, by that I mean if you're having small areas that require detail for high success, the printer can't print at the time the flow and the speed is set, so it stops whenever it has to change a lane, making it a small chance of getting the extruding area stuck.

description.text: I just couldn't resist to openscad this... I'll upload the parametric openscad as soon as I find "a couple of minutes" to clean it and "unhardcodeit" :-P After two minutes of cleaning I spend another two, and another and... The OpenSCAD is not a wonder but it will allow you to play with a few parameters, not very well commented and weirdly named. My apologizes :-P Some pictures: http://www.flickr.com/photos/aubenc/6531579599/in/set-72157628469130335/

Two new stl files available to download! (v2 ones)
I was setting the wall width parameter to 1mm for the "thin walls" stl. It worked fine to me but it may not be the case for you (check it out before printing!). The walls are set to 3mm for the other v2 .stl
"Thin walls" printed in less than 1h (26mm/s) vs more than 2h for the other one(22mm/s). In the other hand, "thin walls" has sharp edges (look at the bottom).
If you use the OpenScad (please do it!) you'll need to use the center and rotate (?) features of ReplicatorG/your software of choice.
The middle ring has been flattened using a 0.85 scale that's lost somewhere in the code !! (2nd circle in the "outer_shape()" module)
I guess I'm forgetting something that should also be said... don't hesitate to ask!

title: RostockMAX belt tensioner with nut captures

description.text:
I added M3 hex nut captures to the pieces in order to make installation and adjustment possible with only a single tool.  
Instead of a single, universal, tensioner design, there are now four.  I also added an extruded pad to the top tensioner pieces that help keep them positioned in the hole on the top of the tower.  
The source files and STLs are not as nice as they could be, but I continue to be pleased with FreeCAD's ability to import STLs and convert them to usable solids.

The design is for M3 screws and nuts, but the FreeCAD source files are included in you would like to change things.  
You will have a total of twelve tensioner pieces, three each of the four designs, and three spacers.  Print the pieces and press the nuts into place.  I've included a plater of all twelve tensioners that you will need.  I didn't include the spacers as I found that different print settings gave better results, so I leave that up to you.  
Install, adjust, and print with tight and straight belts!

author: fluxcore

description.text: I wanted a nice looking, enclosed and reliable 3D printer with great build quality and large envelope. The result: Part-Y! The frame consists of L-shaped aluminium profiles, covered in clear plexiglass with vinyldecals designed by my sister. The printer is completely enclosed with charcoal filters on the air outlet to get rid of fumes. All axes are constructed with high quality professional linear guides. The z axis was originally designed with rods and linear bearings, but I bought the cheapest bearings on ebay and the quality was really bad. The extruder is a Makerbot mk7 for 1.75mm filament, choosen for it's compact size, high reliability and great precision. Current build envelope is limited by the area of the heated bed to 210x210x200 mm, the x and y axes are however capable of 240mm movement. Print-Y is controlled by a Sanguinololu and powered by an internal 400W PSU. I'll add more details with BOM aso later if someone is interested. Bad quality video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qF7fGArkb1c

Thingiverse isn't the greatest place to publish parts lists and build instructions for something with this many parts. I'll put together some sort of homepage/wiki with more details on the printer later. Here is however an (almost) complete parts list so you can get a clue about the total cost of the machine. Electronics:
  • Sanguinololu w. endstops, stepstix, cables aso
  • 3pcs nema17 steppers
  • Makerbot mk7 extruder, I don't use the thermocouple at the moment, 100k thermistor
  • 3pcs 92mm fans
  • PCB heatbed mk2
  • 400W PSU
    • Linear guides and bearings:
    2pcs MR9MN1VON-300-10-10, y-axis
    1pc MR15MN1VON-300-10-10, x-axis
    2pc LM8UU, z-axis Aluminium profiles, 30x30x3mm:
    11pcs 410mm
    4pc 570mm
    1pc 400mm
    1pc 380mm
    1pc 100mm
    4pc 225mm Plexiglass, 3mm:
    2pcs 356x416mm, top and bottom
    2pcs 356x567mm, left and right side
    1pc 356x570, back Plexiglass, 5mm:
    1pc 351x570mm, front, door Printed parts:
    1pc y_motor_bracket.stl
    1pc x_motor_bracket.stl
    1pc z_motor_bracket.stl
    1pc stepper_gear.stl
    1pc screw_gear.stl
    2pc spool_holder.stl
    2pc bearing_holder.stl
    2pc z_nut_trap.stl
    4pcs bar_clamp.stl
    4pcs spacer.stl
    4pcs belt_clamp.stl
    2pcs pulley.stl
    2pcs lm8uu_deep.stl Other:
    2pcs 275mm, 8mm stainless steel rod, smooth bar
    charcoal filter
    PTFE tube for 1.75mm filament (~2mm inside dia)
    6pcs 608zz bearings
    T5 timing belt
    1pc 500 mm hinges for the door
    4pcs rubber feets
    Screws, nuts, washers, m3 and m4! The partnumbers for the miniature linear guides are from a swedish company, www.rollco.se and their naming conventions indicates dimensions: 250/300 is the length in mm, 10-10 is the spacing between the mounting holes and/or ends of slides. 15/9 is the width of the guide in mm. MN1VON indicates the type and dimensions of the sliding block. The dimensions (except for lenght) doesn't really matter and I'm sure there are some cheaper ones with similar dimensions on ebay or whatever. The design of the z-stage was originally with linear bearings, but the lm8uu's that I bought were of really bad quality so I changed one of the z-stage bars with a 250mm miniature linear guide. So, my printer is a bit different then the published design and I recommend you not to buy the cheapest bearings on ebay.

title: Branar Lasher (15mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This miniature was designed (re-sized from my 28mm version) for Wayfarer Tactics, our fast, modular (as in "fully customizable") miniature gaming rules. If you want to check it out, it's totally free here on our site, so give it a download!. It is, of course, useful for any 15mm scale miniature wargame or RPG. You can check out a Sketchfab render here.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

title: Asynchronous Lamp Shade for Ikea table lamp base

description.text:
This is the second in a series of lamp shades made for Ikea table lamp bases using type "G" LED light bulbs. This sample was printed by a Flashforge Creator X @230C using economy natural ABS from Matter Hackers. I wanted very thin (1.5mm) surfaces, but I had warping problems. I printed a sample at 2mm, but light did not transmit as well as this one at 1.5. I will try again on a hot day with my printer top completely closed to see if I still have warping problems.

Please feel free to make suggestions.

I named this character by Asuka, and she’s inspired by Bushi (Japanese warrior)

Asuka is an orphan who have never seen her parents.
She read Bushido from her youth and was trained into a warrior to guard a wealthy family, Owada.
She found out that her family was kill by the Owada and she was very angry.
She decided to do the right thing.
So she left the wealthy family and start to punish villains in the village by killing them and giving out their money to poor people.
At the same time, she’s also planning her revenge to the Owada...

print_settings.Notes:: For this particular printer model it's a relatively easy machine to use in order to create 3D printing creations. However, sometimes this printer model has its material jammed. As an important tip if the STL from any of the 3D printing sharing sites or a creation you made yourself and it isn't fixed then for this printing model it will not create the 3D creation. In order to fix the STL file go to a Microsoft website called Microsoft 3D Model Repair Service. Besides that personally out of all the programs you can use to create a 3D model yourself I strongly prefer using the 3D program SketchUp Pro 2015. Overall in order to actually print your creation is as follows in simple steps:  1. After logging to the computer connected to the printer model by inputing the password.  2. Then input your flash drive. 3. Click on File then click on open STL.  4. Before step 5 make sure to check the size, layer resolution, model interior, etc. 5. Next input your 3D creation by clicking Add to Pack.        6. Finally, click Print.

description.text: Overall I used a an easy 3D program called sketchUp Pro 2015. Since I used this particular program it was relatively easy to create the 3D model. It was even easier by using the specified printer brand stated below. Thus there was no missing pieces when the model was printed as an example. It was a fun creation to make and as a result it turned out to be pretty good 3D version of the design I made on SketchUp Pro 2015. If you want to make a cool 3D monster snake then this is the design for you.

Notes:

For this particular printer model it's a relatively easy machine to use in order to create 3D printing creations. However, sometimes this printer model has its material jammed. As an important tip if the STL from any of the 3D printing sharing sites or a creation you made yourself and it isn't fixed then for this printing model it will not create the 3D creation. In order to fix the STL file go to a Microsoft website called Microsoft 3D Model Repair Service. Besides that personally out of all the programs you can use to create a 3D model yourself I strongly prefer using the 3D program SketchUp Pro 2015. Overall in order to actually print your creation is as follows in simple steps: 1. After logging to the computer connected to the printer model by inputing the password. 2. Then input your flash drive. 3. Click on File then click on open STL. 4. Before step 5 make sure to check the size, layer resolution, model interior, etc. 5. Next input your 3D creation by clicking Add to Pack. 6. Finally, click Print.

Sometimes the model doesn't need to be put into a bath because as an exception if the supports for the model fell off on its own then there's no need to do it. So if what i mentioned previously did not occur then once the 3D creation is completed then immediately put the 3D model creation into a bath, which is made of sodium hydroxide otherwise known as NaOH. It's highly caustic solution and dangerous so avoid contact with exposed skin. The 3D model creation must be left in the bath for about 9hrs. Then take it out of the bath and dry it off until it is completely dry, which will be about 24hrs so I suggest letting it dry overnight. For the following next day use sand paper to sand the entire surface and smooth out the lines, which will lead finally to painting it. As a result the finished product was just like the design I made on the 3D program sketchUp Pro 2015, but because depending on the type of color I used to create the model some details weren't visible.

Before I designed the 3D model creation I used the 3D program called SketchUp Pro 2015. In the beginning I started with simple shape such as a triangle for the head and then by using the free hand option I drew the body so it would curve side to side as if in motion. Afterwards I would extrude the flat pieces for each part of the model upwards. Next I added detail by using two different shapes in one option that contains multiple types of shapes. Then I would draw circle shapes in the eye and delete it. Lastly I did a last check to see that the design wasn't missing any parts or the shapes etched into the model are not too drastic, but just enough to be noticeable once it is printed. So to conclude after the previous step above just for fun I painted it with the colors below similar to the color pattering of a coral snake.

I was looking for a small simple iPad stand on Thingiverse and I only found bulky ones! So I decided to make my own and here it is.   
The iPad sits very stable in both positions (landscape and vertically). The original stand I uploaded worked well with the iPad in landscape but not as well with it sitting vertically. So I edited the design by increasing the length of the back leg a bit while curving it, and now it works well sitting in both positions!   
This should also fit other tablets and even the iPad Mini quite well!

print_settings.Notes:: Those holes are for the pennies between the sheets.

title: Penny Flyer (NOT! for CO2 laser cutters!)

description.text:
Update! Warning! Not for CO2 Laser cutters! The foam is made of a version of VINYL which is deadly to lasers. R.I.P. my first laser tube. ;-(

A simple 9-inch flyer made out of craft foam and pennies in the ring for heft.
Fast to cut, easy to assemble, and incredibly fun to play with.
I have a video, but 3GP is not supported, sorry.

Printer:

FSL Hobby 40w Laser Cutter

Notes:

!! Be sure to delete the ring of holes for the outside sheets !!

Those holes are for the pennies between the sheets.

Assembly:

Minimum, cut one sheet with the holes, and two sheets without the holes.
Use tacky-glue, or a glue stick for flexibility with the holes being between the solid sheets, of course.
Be sure to glue the pennies to at least one of the solid sheets.

I offset the cutouts so that all three colors would show. You can alter the design a bit by deleting every third wedge of cutouts, then assembling them with each color having their own wedge.

Inspiration:

They sell foam flyers at the store where I work. Frankly, I was not impressed with them for the price, so I decided to create my own version. This is the result. :-)

Customizing your flyers:

You can cut out more solid sheets for extra stiffness.
Colors and positioning are completely up to you.
The number of pennies is up to you to choose, perhaps with dome trial and error. Maybe even heavier items like washers?

print_settings.Notes:: Since I used this type of printer brand model it was different from other 3D printer models. It is more simple than a more advanced 3D printer so I suggest using simple to few detail type model creations for these type of printers. The 3D printer itself does have technical issues so be aware of that and it takes up to 5 mins to warm up before it will print the creation. So in oder to create a model in this printer it's described in several steps. 1. Choose the 3D program called Cura. 2. Click on File and then scroll until you find Load Model File. 3. Next, check the layers in view menu. 4. then cut object if necessary. 5. Make sure the first layer is on the printing bed. 6. Next, save it as a G-Code. 7. Then Open the Folder where the G-code is presiding. 8. Double click on the G-Code File. Before you go into step nine first check if the design is the product you want before continuing. 9. Now go to the 3D program called Repetier-Host mac. 10. Lastly, click Run, which will start the  printing process and then wait until it is done.

description.text: Overall, this type of 3D printer is more simple than other more advanced 3D printer model brands. So I suggest to create from simple to medium amount of detail in order to have a better resulting product for this type of 3D printer. Since it is an older 3D printer model brand it requires more patience because more mistakes can occur, so be aware of that fact. Even though it is along process to create a 3D model creation it's with the effort in the long run to minimize technical errors.

So in oder to create a model in this printer it's described in several steps. 1. Choose the 3D program called Cura. 2. Click on File and then scroll until you find Load Model File. 3. Next, check the layers in view menu. 4. then cut object if necessary. 5. Make sure the first layer is on the printing bed. 6. Next, save it as a G-Code. 7. Then Open the Folder where the G-code is presiding. 8. Double click on the G-Code File. Before you go into step nine first check if the design is the product you want before continuing. 9. Now go to the 3D program called Repetier-Host mac. 10. Lastly, click Run, which will start the printing process and then wait until it is done.

From using the 3D printer mentioned above with the type of simple design I created it turned out to be a great success. As a result the finished product was just like the design I made on the 3D program sketchUp Pro 2015. If the design is not simple and has a lot of detail then it may not be a great success as the final product. Finally then all that's left is to paint the 3D model creation.

Based upon the inspiration, which was an every day object I chose the key. So to begin I used a specific shape that was a hexagon, which was used for the head part of the key. Any specific shapes can found in the 3D program within the option box that contains different geometrical shapes. Then I chose the rectangle shape in the same option box and created the body part of the key. I used the Free hand option box to draw the edges on one side of the body part of the key. Next, I deleted the highlighted portion, which was the edges. Then, I did some extra details to make it seem more like a key actually would in reality. Lastly, just for fun afterwards I painted the key of mystery with the colors below.

Heating milk in the microwave is a convenient way to make espresso coffee, but it never gets hot enough due to localised hotspots boiling over before the bulk of the fluid is heated through. This device continually stirs the milk or coffee during heating to ensure the fluid is uniformly heated throughout. Now you can enjoy scolding hot microwave coffee without the mess.

https://youtu.be/rn385hXYRq8

Just add bamboo skewers cut to fit and your choice of food grade plastic or wooden stirrer(s). A variety of configurations are possible. Legs can be long enough for the device to stand up on its own to make it easier to catch drips or just long enough to keep it on the mug. The turning arms can be single or double sided for balance or compactness respectively.

Perhaps a light coating of wax would serve as a food safe lubricant for the gears, which can sometimes twist and jam on rough edges of the print.

I'm using this on a hobbyking ST360 setup. My concept is that I wanted an anti-vibration mount for my APM 2.5, although this should work for any controller, where I could easily attach and detach modules between multicopters. I'm currently only using one mount, but plan on making more. Definitely one for my vTX so I can swap it with the camera easily to other RC vehicles. The APM is mounted using O-Rings to reduce any vibration. For now I'm not using my GPS mount, but I plan to use it on my larger quad I'm making. I included my original base design, although I redesigned it due to weight. The new design is much lighter and has more areas to route wires/zipties. I printed ABS with 15% infill and had the following results:
Quad Base - 42g
Quad Base Light Version - 25g
Camera Mount Module - 9g
GPS Mount - 13g I've included the Alibre Design files for people to modify if desired, along with a modular connector to use as a start for new module designs. Although my holes are aligned for the ST360 frame, it shouldn't be a big deal to move them to match other frames. Or redesign the base to replace the top panel of your quad (something I'm planning). I made the modular connectors have long slots so they could double for double use for battery straps/zip ties, and easily adjust for length when connecting modules if needed. You can see on my quad I also used the camera shroud from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:76582 and the APM 2.5 case from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36883. 09/26/2013 - I added a new module for a 3DR style telemetry radio. You can see it attached to my new quad I'm making in the photo.

I printed everything in ABS with 15% infill.  
The holes are all for M3 screws/nuts.  And I made the anti vibration holes tight so you'll have to force in the M3 screws.  That way they work more like studs than screws.  The O-rings I used were R-04 7x1.5mm.  
The GPS mount is designed to sit on the studs above the O-rings and be held on with M3 nuts to the studs.

description.text: Chattanooga Tennessee. The vertical scale is 1.2X. It was constructed using 1 arcsecond resolution SRTM data from the Space Shuttle (about 1.6 million facets). This software was created using a new and, as yet, unreleased version of SRTM2STL. The source code for creating files at 3 arcsecond resolution is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

Imaged is my first printout of one-half of the PDB 4RHW molecule (APAF-1 & Caspase-9 complex). The printout is very rigid adding in reinforcing connections. After printing, a few unstable locations were identified. The main weak point being the chloride atom found near the center of the molecule. Additional reinforcing connections were added and included within the provided file.

The APAF-1 is a key player in the execution of apoptosis, or programmed cell death. Oligomerization of 7 APAF-1 molecules a structure called the "apoptosome" forms. The apoptosome converts pro-caspase-9 to caspase-9 which is important for the activation of cellular proteases involved in apoptosis. This protein molecule is interesting in that it only contains alpha-helices.

The original PDB file (4RHW: http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=4RHW) was manipulated using VMD (http://www.ks.uiuc.edu/Research/vmd/) to remove water and sulfate molecules. The protein in the PDB file is a dimer so half the protein was isolated and represented. The structural representation in VMD was then set to NewCartoon and exported out of VMD as an .STL file.

The .STL file was imported into Tinkercad (https://www.tinkercad.com/). Within Tinkercad, reinforcing braces and supports were added manually. The reinforcing braces between the alpha-helices are meant to be left within the molecule to increase structural rigidity whereas the base supports were added to facilitate the printing process.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Instructions

Should be printed with both raft and supports (may take up to 40+ hours using the print settings specified).

Printed out using Makerbot Replicator 5 with MEDIUM QUALITY. After printing, the removal of the raft and the supports is straight forward.The reinforcing connections give the model sufficient rigidity to allow for most of the raft and supports to be easily removed. EXTRA CAUTION should be used when removing the scaffolding around the chlorine atom. In the original model, the chlorine atom fell off during the removal of the raft and supports. Extra reinforcing connections were added to this location into the provided print file.

description.text: This is a box to help make passive T568B wiretaps. Wiretaps let you intercept data to assist in diagnosing internet connectivity issues. Wiretaps can also be very useful in understanding how data packets are transmitted between computers. Although this can be used for skimming data, it is illegal to do so without consent. It's also important to keep in mind, the maximum speed the tap can operate at is 100 megabits per second.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes:

You may need to change the cable size in the scad file.

To use the wiretap...

The only tool you need is a pair of scissors. Use the included diagram for help making the tap. The 8 cylinder caps are to pinch the wire ends together. You only need 4 caps to make the tap but you will need extras, trust me.

Plug the victim cable into the computer you want to tap.
Plug the WAN cable into your Internet modem.
Plug either the Rx or the Tx cable into your computer.
Use Wireshark to intercept the data.

Note: Rx means receive and Tx means transmit.

I wanted to make a paint mixer blade that could be affixed to a threaded rod and attached to a power drill. This is an attempt at a simple design. This model doesn't have a fixed size and can be resized as needed. This model is untested and will be printed soon.
UPDATE: I printed the mixing blade and sent a cheapo long masonary bit through the piece (easiest way to make it work with a drill). The bit went through the inside bottom hole about 1/4" and then I used an epoxy to lock the bit to the piece. So far it mixes really well! As a warning, do not start the drill when the blade is at the surface of the paint (you will spray it everywhere). Start with a low speed and then increase gradually. When spinning, this blade can be dangerous! Use with caution and safety in mind.

Not much else to say other than its a fun flash drive stand. I made it to hold the flash drive that contained the files for my English project to impress my teacher. I got a 100 :) I figured I would upload it so that others could use it. Enjoy!

FlashForge Creator Pro

Doesn't Matter

How I Designed This:

Materials:
1) Autodesk Inventor 2016
2) 20 Minutes of Free Time
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6dD6Lb4Ryux

Will update when finished, box box and hoper are now built, next is to think of a way to add a gear motor with chain drive.

IF ANYONE NEEDS EXTRA PHOTOS THEN LET ME KNOW WHAT OF AND I WILL POST THEM HERE. Also i still have the tinker cad files and am willing to give the link if any one needs to adjust anything.

We had printed and built the compost shredder we’d seen on Thingiverse which had been put up by THYMARK
It worked reasonably well, but there just wasn’t enough “beef” to it for our “wants”.
Casting around a few ideas and we came up with a design that has wooden grinding gears.
To be sure that the teeth would hold up, I went to a wood specialty shop and asked for the hardest wood they had in stock. I was expecting maple or ash, but he had some Arizona Iron Wood. One look and a quick hefting told me all I needed to know. This stuff is truly like “iron”, tight grain and VERY dense. Perfect for what I wanted. BTW this stuff “ain’t cheap”. One 8 ft. length would do me just fine. We used the original end piece design to hold the bearings. They’re perfect.
I had some left over 1” pre-punch square tubing from the first one. I took the grinder apart to get the dimensions of the gear teeth. Traced a gear outline on the wood, outside profile and inside to be able to cut them out. This is where a scroll saw or band saw with a fine blade is perfect.
The original design shows four teeth on a side. Like Tim the Tool Man says “More Power” ,,, we went with 6 gears on each side. This is where patience and a steady hand is good to have. The wood is very tough to cut with a scroll saw. I ended up using a band saw to get the outline. Be careful or you’ll break the blade (guilty look) .. To get the inner hole cut, at first I was drilling out a few holes to get the scroll saw blade set up and then follow the lines. After a few times, I got out my Forstner bit and drilled away the majority of the excess material. NOTE HERE ,,,, be very careful drilling, the thing can get away and with those sharp teeth can destroy your fingers. I used a drill vise to hold each one as I was drilling. As I got each hole finished I tested it on the tubing. Any “modification” (ie make larger) was done with my wood rasp to ensure a tight fit on the tubing. I was careful to mark the position of how they fit and in which order they went. We also printed the spacers for the teeth. They slid onto the square tubing quite well. As for the end gears they got printed too, BUT they ended up a whole bunch thicker than the original.
Now as for how to turn the teeth. I got some ¾ threaded rod and about a dozen nuts and flat washers. I measured the tubing length to accommodate the teeth and spacers. Putting two nuts on a bit of the threaded rod and inserting it inside the tubing was a bit tricky. You’ll need to grind off some of the end of the nut to make it fit in line with the other nut plus be able to slide inside the tubing. A grinding wheel is handy for this. (WEAR YOUR SAFETY GLASSES) To make sure it wouldn’t slide out I used my MIG welder to fasten the nuts inside of the tubing,
To be sure the rod turned inside of the bearings we printed some circles to go over the rod and inside of the bearings. (Think a round shim) The gears have a HEX internal of 1 1/8 to allow the nut to slide in. Because of the thickness of the gear I ground down the thickness of one of the nuts to be able to have two nuts in each gear. I held them in place with a flat washer and two nuts jammed tight to allow freedom of motion yet not slid out of alignment.
As for the side panels, we tried printing them. Our printer just wasn’t up to the task (It’s only a 12 x 12) some of the “work” was too close to the edge even with putting it on a diagonal. I decided to get some 3 ½ wide PVC molding at the Local Lowe’s. One 8 foot length was fine.
I cut the length to fit on the end panels with a bit of “overage” by about 1/16 th. The drill press did the work of the 3/8 holes to line up with the end panels. Some Helicoil inserts made sure the mounting bolts or studs (which ever you desire) would have a secure bite.
As for the angled guides that ride on the spacers, I used my brace and bit to drill out a proper hole (for me this came to 2 1/8 … not wanting to spend the money on a hole saw I did that part by hand) to get the center use your small framing square to make a 45 degree angle on each side and where they cross use a center punch to allow your bit to start.
Chop saw to cut the pieces to length. I decided to make the centerline cut a bit off center to allow for the saw blade kerf. (I know that uses up a bit more material but it’s worth it for the finish look.) Once cut to fit I put the blade at an angle to make the cuts that fit over the spacer. NOTE WELL … BE VERY CAREFUL OF YOUR FINGERS WHEN USING THIS SAW. …. UNLESS YOU LIKE THE NICK NAME OF “STUMPY”
Once the guides were cut to fit, I placed them inside of the grinder and gave it a few turns to check for freedom of motion. EXCELLENT result.
I then marked the inside of the side panel to preset for drilling some mounting screws. HINT once marked out drill a small pilot hole from the inside and counter sink the outside for wood screws. Align and pre drill for each screw.
I put my 3/8 drill to it and checked for smoothness of operation. SWEEEET. I did find that I do need a more powerful drill to be able to grind some of the thicker items or I’m gonna have to make a gear reduction set up for the power.

tooth size
x and y, veries between 82 and 85mm
z 20.0 to20.5mm high
79.5 x,y
27.0 z

bearing side plate 16mm x 90mm x 160mm

4x ball bearings - SKF 6006 ZZ or 2RS
helicoil kit 5/16 or metric equivalent plus bolts
3/4 rod for the center
bunch of 3/4 nuts and washers
8ft length of wood (harder the better)

some parts from the compost shredder project are also compatible

added to the stl files are templates as well as full prints so depending which way this is made then not all files are needed

needed stl files
4 x bearing spacers,
2 x bearing sides,
same number as teeth spacers as cutter teeth,
the shredder spacer stl is a template only.

rest is up to the builder.

some tools needed.
grinder
welder
skill or band saw (preferably both)
if welding or cutting is needed then pm me and can might be able to help.

comments.text:
Hi Stefi,
I have this and it is very functional and efficient.
Its's just that for making filaments out of recycled plastic, I need to get plastic particles, of specific size. So I was thinking about puting a screen under it, so that only the particles of good size come trough and the bigger ones go back to grinding.
But I don't think that would quite work like I imagined, since the teeth are separating after the plastic goes trough, so there will be no grip.
Any idea about this?
Thank you.
comments.author: riri_hojita

comments.text:
We wrap up bigger chunks in cloth then either beat it with a hammer or crush in a vice to make it smaller and weaker and then grind it all a few times, we then pour small bits at a time in to a printed strainer with 6mm holes, anything that falls through we extrude, bigger stuff goes through again.
we made a big wooden box which the grinder is screwed to so nothing moves around.
I don't know why your teeth move around as they should be as tight as possible butted up against the bearings and plastic teeth will be useless.
as for grip, if you need more then maybe scroll down near the bottom of comments see what brunoschoofs said, about adding knives to the spacers, i am not sure how this would work but it maybe worth thinking about
comments.author: riri_hojita

author: nsolcis

description.text:
I decided to try mounting the J-Head from Geeetech on my G2S and needed a mount. I made two variants. One version uses two screws to lock the J-Head in place, the other version has a removable part that is screwed in place to lock the J-Head in place. After experimenting with both, I decided the single piece version works better.

Yeah, it's a single extruder and I basically gave up messing with the dual extruder setup. Too much trouble trying to get the extruders and bed level, so I am switching to a single extruder. When I get a chance I will make a CNC replacement for the spider that has more clearance to mount two J-heads.

http://www.geeetech.com/metal-longdistance-jhead-with-the-cable-for-bowden-extruder-p-789.html

description.text:
This is a model of the benchmade 44s butterfly knife. I always liked making knock-off names so that explains the title! There is a bit of a story behind this model. I showed my friend this (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36510) and immediately he wanted to one-up me! (he loves balisongs and was jealous of my 3d printing capabilities but its all in good fun) he is in the process of making one out of metal. I was originally going to make this one out of steel and use it as my counter attack ;) but after thinking about it for a bit I decided I wanted to make a different one that I could make more easily out of metal. So i optimized this one for 3d printing and wanted to put it on thingiverse. so without further adjure, I hope you enjoy it!

edit

there is a comb blade version of the blade to make it more functional!

Instructions

After you have 2 handle files and one blade file printed it's as east as putting 2 m2 bolts through the holes and putting a nylon locknut on the end or you don't deserve to have a 3d printer! Kidding! But is should be that simple. depending on how you print it you might just have to widen the holes on the blade and the bolts should just thread right into the plastic.

author: jhc678

description.text:
The video will show you what you will need and the steps to make a battery that has enough power to light up a small LED.

How to build this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wdGPC-sCg-A

Some notes not in the video:
You can use cloth, napkins, or cardboard as a replacement for the grill wipes, I just had the best results the wipes.
The zinc will oxidize, the vinegar will evaporate causing the battery to stop working after a few hours.
Add salt to the vinegar and stir until it dissolves. This will create a stronger acid and give you a higher voltage.
You don't have to use all 9 pennies. Just stop when you have 6 volts.

Thank you for your support!

comments.text: Wouldn't these work better with older pennies?  The copper content of pennies minted since 1982 only have 2.5% copper.  The rest is zinc.  This looks like a cool project.  I'm just wondering if it would work better if the metals were more dissimilar.
comments.author: Sparky6548

comments.text: If you can find enough old pennies and can clean off the oxidation, that sounds good to me! Now I'm curious what results you would get with older pennies. Thank you for the comment.
comments.author: Sparky6548

comments.text: I came here to say the same thing. https://www.comsol.com/blogs/electroplating-u-s-mint-makes-penny/

title: HBP Wire Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Heated Build Platform Wire Guide for the ToM. I was unhappy with the other wire guides as they didn't keep the wires away from X axis, Y axis and the heated surface through the range of X and Y as well as keeping helping keep the strain off the connector. I figured the solution was to pull the wires further out to the front. I use this in conjunction with this strain relief: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12341
Because of the thumbscrews I'm using to level the HBP platform, I mount thing 12341 on the opposite side, so it should be mirror'd in replicatorG in the Y axis, and you need to file/cut a bit off the slope to clear the 2 pin HBP ABP motor connector. UPDATE: Dan has derived and updated this design to remove the need to disconnect the cables and provide vertical / horizontal mounting options. I'm now using Dan's: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15327

Print both halves and glue together with acetone.  Mount on the HBP with a M3 Nut / Bolt.  You'll need to drill a 3mm hole in the plywood to attach the wire guide via the rounded slot.
Carefully disconnect the HBP connector (the circuit board traces can easily come off).  Make a note of the order of the wires, and use a knife or small screwdriver to push the release tab on each wire on the connector to remove each wire from the connector.  Thread the wires through the torus on the guide and click back in the connector.
Resist the temptation to move the HBP by grabbing the cable guides.

tags: HBP Wire Guide Heated Build Platform Strain Relief

comments.text: FWIW, I just published a simple derivative of this design -- thing 15327.  I could not mark this guide as its ancestor as the UI told me that 14687 disallows derivatives.   Main differences are that the wires do not need to be disconnected to apply, and the guide can be bolted to a horizontal member of the HBP or a vertical member.
comments.author: dnewman

comments.text: Okay, now it's marked as an ancestor.  Wouldn't let me do it earlier -- now it does.  Both times, using the ancestry tab.  Likely some sort of bug or db hiccup.

comments.text: I've had bigger prints where the thumbscrews you and I are using hit my wooden frame on my TOM.. I can see this long extension really messing with that as well.  My only solution would be to mount the cables out then immediately down under the HBP.  You've never hit this on the frame or strained the cables that way?  Just curious.

description.text:
This is a work in progress UAV. The wingspan is around 54in. It is meant for 1/2 in square tubing (wood/aluminum) for the spars. The ribs should be spaced out 3in apart and 2.5in for the wingtip pieces. This model is meant for a monokote covering and is meant for a VTOL platform (Like the Google wing project) but it can still be used for a normal airplane. It does have a symmetrical airfoil but if you thinks that's too much, let me know and I'll make a semi- symmetrical airfoil. ATTENTION: Airfoil ribs might need to be cut in half to fit on most printers! A redesign for a small 38in wing span is on its way!

UPDATES:

4-6-16- Added Vertical stabilizers (4) that also acts as landing struts (for VTOLs). These stabilizers are optional. If used, elevons are needed. These are not rudders but can be made into rudders.

I was working on a project in OpenSCAD that needed smooth curves. I was excited to find some Bezier curve libraries, but as I used them I remembered why awkward thing about Bezier curves: they're hard to design with if you want precise control. You move a control point, and it pulls the curve one way, but it also affects other areas of the curve, so you have to nudge adjacent control points the other way to compensate, and then repeat forever.

What I wanted was to tell OpenSCAD exactly where I wanted the curve to go, with a few points, and have it make a smooth curve passing between those points. That's a spline. I couldn't find any spline libraries for OpenSCAD. So I made this one.

The main module, spline.scad, is directly usable with no other dependencies. Grab the zip file instead if you want to look at the examples, as they're dependent on a couple of other modules.

Functionality included:

  • spline ribbons - a 2D splined line with a given width
  • spline walls - like a ribbon, but extruded to a given height
  • Several varieties of spline noodles - shapes extruded along a splined path, including ramen (circular cross-section), udon (square cross-section), and sausage (OK, that's not a noodle, but it's a ramen noodle with rounded ends), plus a hose which knocks out the center of a ramen noodle to a predefined width.
  • Both a regular lathed spline and a lathed pot, which is handy for making a thin-walled lathed object that must fit around something else (the initial motivation).
  • Open and closed versions of most things - for open-ended curvy lines or closed loops.
  • Several examples, pictured here.

Limitations

Sadly, the noodles look pretty great in the preview, much of the time, but the current OpenSCAD code chokes on them while rending with internal assertion failures, especially if you do Boolean operations with other shapes. The other shapes compile fine, though, and reasonably quickly.

Also, the approach to cross-section orientation I'm using in the lofting algorithm sometimes breaks at sharp transitions. Some of this could be fixable without changing the interface; some of it may require manually specifying normal vectors at each path point. I'll work more on that.

I welcome your input if you want to work on these problems. Feel free to fork the code from my GitHub.

Also: I developed this using OpenSCAD 2016.02.09 and it uses some recent features, so it won't be compatible with older versions. OpenSCAD has been backward-compatible in my experience; if anyone has a reason to prefer an older version, I'd like to hear about it.

The basic implementation comes from this forum post via this blog post. The "noodle" extrusion implementation is modified from this code and other modules from Kit's GitHub repo. Thanks very much for sharing, Kit and Oskar!

Hi there,
This is my playstation 2 mini arcade.
I was given this playstation a couple of years ago.
And i thought I should put it to good use.

The Arcade is made out of MDF sides and the rest is all 3D printed.
I am installing E.L. wire for coolness to the screen side.

As you can see I only started yesterday but I will continue to update the images as it nears finishing.

Once is finished I will give it to a co-workers son who comes to sit with me while at work to see what we can print next from thingiverse.
He loves 3D printing.

You might be able to do without the brackets I have made.
Because I do not have a circular saw, i thought i cut cut the internal shelf pieces with a jigsaw then hide my crooked cuts in the brackets!
Luckily my friend Steve cut them for me and I didnt need to use them.
So you have that option.

no screws on this project, just construction glue! but make yours to your skill level.

my woodworking skills and tools are not very good.

description.text: This is the power wheel chair joystick from the 3D Printing in Practice presentation at AOTA 2016. The source 123d files are included for your use.

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm at the swivel, .3 everywhere else

Infill:

15% or greater

Notes:

Use PETG or another bio safe, washable material for best results. Nylon and polycarbonite also work well, but PET is the easiest to print by far

Bill of Materials

Additional parts will run between $5 and $45 depending on if you want to include sound or not.

In addition to the 3d printed parts, you'll need
4 uSwitches (http://www.amazon.com/Micro-Limit-Switch-Roller-Action/dp/B00H8TIEHW/ref=sr_1_1?s=industrial&ie=UTF8&qid=1459951417&sr=1-1&keywords=micro+switch)
1 M8 bolt of whatever length you want to use for the stick itself
1 AA battery holder (http://www.amazon.com/WAYLLSHINE%C2%AE-Dozen-Battery-Holder-Black/dp/B013GNC08C?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s06)
1 spring that will fit over your bolt (5mm diameter) and at whatever spring rate you want
1 sound trigger, if you want sound (http://www.amazon.com/Adafruit-Audio-FX-Sound-Board/dp/B00Q3U42DM?ie=UTF8&psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00)
1 RJ45 keystone (http://www.amazon.com/Generic-10-pack-Keystone-Punch-Down-Ethernet/dp/B014RAT7ZC/ref=sr_1_3?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1459951580&sr=1-3-spons&keywords=RJ45+keystone&psc=1)

title: Omniwheel x 3 robot frame and mounts

description.text: I'm making a little robot from some cheap omniwheels with a friend using S04NF continuous rotation servos and 3d printed frame. The frame is a regular hexagon with attachment points for the servos in a triangle configuration. Also included are press fit mounts to connect the omniwheels to the servos. Our omniwheels are very similar to these hobbyking ones but have an inner diameter of 8mm rather than 10mm. It's easy to adjust the oozby file to whatever diameter you need. The M5 bolts in the picture aren't strictly necessary. It press fit's quite firmly on to the servo mounting tabs, but for extra security you can loop a zip tie through each of the bolt blocks behind each servo tab and tighten it down with some pliers instead of bolts. You can also change the diameter of the servo tab holes to be smaller and screw the servos on to it.
print two bot-plates and three servo mounts. I used PLA - ABS isn't as stiff so it may not press fit as firmly, but a few zip ties or bolts will do the trick.

description.text:
There are several configurations of the Commodore uIEC/SD card adapter from Retro Innovations. A friend had the configuration picture above so none of the designs on Thingiverse quite fit his. This design is based on Rhys79's and also provides access to the three buttons mounted on the SD card board.

I know this isn't the best-looking print and the lid looks like crap - my printer bed was dirty.

This was also an excuse to start playing learning how to design with OnShape.com

Printer:

Cobblebot Basic

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed with 2 perimeters to give the sidewalls a little more strength. It's still a thin shell but once the lid is in place it's more than strong enough for the application.

This was designed using OnShape.com which is an online 3D parametric design software. A limited account is free but you can do a lot with it and also learn how to do a pareamtric design similar to using SolidWorks. SolidWorks is more feature rich but it's also cost about $4k for the software license.

I realized I forgot the pad on the lid from Rhys79's design. This helps lock the SD card in it's slot. It still can be locked in the slot but the pad would make it better. Will add this on my next update
